conclusion: To determine the temperature of the gas at state B, use the ideal gas law and properties of the processes shown in the p-V diagram.
The process from A to B is a vertical line on the p-V diagram, indicating that the volume remains constant (isochoric process).
For an isochoric process, the pressure changes while the volume stays the same.
The ideal gas law is given by PV = nRT.
Since the volume is constant from A to B, the relation between the states A and B is PA/TA = PB/TB.
At state A: PA = 3 x 10^5 Pa, VA = 1 x 10^-3 m³, TA = 27°C = 300 K.
At state B: PB = 1 x 10^5 Pa, VB = 1 x 10^-3 m³.
Rearrange the relation to solve for TB: TB = TA x (PB/PA).
Substitute the known values: TB = 300 K x (1 x 10^5 Pa / 3 x 10^5 Pa) = 100 K.
The temperature of the gas at state B is 100 K.
